This festival should be banned. What a shit idea.

item.description:
@lothy wrote:

[quote=“yakman, post:67, topic:331234”]Lothy, if you have problems with some of the church’s beliefs, doesn’t that by definition mean you have problems with people following the church’s beliefs, i.e. catholics.

how do you manage to disagree with the teachings yet agree with the followers?[/quote]
I believe that the followers have a right to follow. If they want to believe in something then good for them, that’s their business.

item.title: Thousands watch Sydney's gay and lesbian Mardi Gras
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

Oh, I thought it was a pretty clear cut response. I was born into a family that had me baptised, and I even went to a catholic high school – but I don’t believe in, or practice, any aspect of the religion. Many of my morals are in line with the church’s belief system, but there are many areas that I disagree with.

I believe that a person should be able to do what they want, so long as no harm comes to anyone else due to that person’s actions or inactions.
I also dispute the view that the church has with regard to life; I don’t believe that a baby is ‘alive’ in the sense that we are at the time the sperm and egg meet, so I don’t have any qualms with abortion… I don’t support its use as a method contraception, though.

With that said, you should come to the realisation that I have nothing against homosexual relationships. I also have nothing against people practicing catholicism.

Read full topic

item.title: Thousands watch Sydney's gay and lesbian Mardi Gras
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:60, topic:331234”][quote author=Lothy link=topic=427593.msg3141454#msg3141454 date=1267574388]
infringing on the religious view of others in their own place of worship is disrespectful.
[/quote]

Sure, let’s pussyfoot around the issue some more.

Or we could man up and tell them to stop using fairy tales as an excuse to bitch at normal folk.

Zomg religion is untouchable. Pfft.[/quote]
They’ve as much right to believe in their religion as you have to not believe in it, as Jme has to smoke weed, and as Kane has to be homosexual. None of the above harm other people.
Of course it could be said that religious folk will cross the line by forcing their views onto others… but then Jme could cross the line by getting high and robbing a store, or Kane could force himself onto someone.

See my point? Everything needs to be balanced here. If you’re going for the extreme then you’re undermining someone’s rights somewhere along the line (even if it’s ‘just’ the right to self determination with regards to religious belief). Religious folk going around bible bashing isn’t on – but neither is telling someone that they can’t, or shouldn’t, believe in its teachings in the way they see fit.

Read full topic

item.title: Thousands watch Sydney's gay and lesbian Mardi Gras
item.dc:creator: @yakman yakman
item.description:
@yakman wrote:

[quote=“Speljohan, post:54, topic:331234”][quote author=sppt link=topic=427593.msg3141169#msg3141169 date=1267543050]
Ironic how this is happening right around something like Mardi Grass in the Netherlands. To make the coincidence even weirder, a gay man was refused his communion stuff, because the dutch division of the catholic church thinks you need to have the “right preference” to be able to do it.
[/quote]I can agree about this stuff actually. The Church has clearly stated to be anti-homosexuality for a long time, why would a homosexual couple even want to get married in a Church?[/quote]

I can see what you mean, I’ve never understood why some homosexuals are religious. They actually contribute to the organisation that is the biggest source of their persecution, its handing nails to your torturer!

I could also never understand religious feminists.

Also I heard this word that might be of interest. From now on anybody who is both gay and atheist will be known as a gatheist.

Read full topic

item.title: Thousands watch Sydney's gay and lesbian Mardi Gras
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

I don’t really have a whole problem with the homosexual marriage, so long as they aren’t stepping on anyone else’s toes. Which means that, should they get married, it should take place outside of a church. It’s one thing to have the law mark you as equals in the eyes of the law, or to have it allow things such as the union of two people, but I think going that extra mile and infringing on the religious view of others in their own place of worship is disrespectful.

Read full topic

item.title: Thousands watch Sydney's gay and lesbian Mardi Gras
item.dc:creator: @XxKanexX Kane.
item.description:
@XxKanexX wrote:

[quote=“la­wl, post:44, topic:331234”][quote author=Kane. link=topic=427593.msg3141001#msg3141001 date=1267506229]

Kane the issue isn’t that homosexuals are having a massive party. It’s that they’re having a massive party on the streets. Behind closed doors everyone is free to do what they like, but when it comes to the streets people should act in a way that won’t disturb others.

And yes, I am quite disturbed by drag queens and cross dressers. I don’t think it’s necessary for them to behave like that in public and I’m not the only person disturbed by that.

I’m not trying to debate homosexuality. I just don’t think a massive demonstration of sexuality is appropriate for the streets.

It’s on the streets because It’s an outlandish statement- It’s for recognition- To leave Its footprint.
That’s what everyone’s been saying the whole time.

You think anyone’s going to notice or care If It’s a giant house party?

Why isn’t it necessary for them to behave like that? Because that’s not how you live? Because It’s different? Try being a little more open minded, and less ignorant.

You’re saying the same things over and over again and there is no substance left in your “points”.
It all comes down to that’s not how you like it, It’s not what you want, therefore It shouldn’t exist.

Try reversing the situation. Though It’s hard to feel the impact without actually reversing.

[/quote]
it sounds like u wanna put ur dick in my ass gay fag[/quote]
I have taste, sorry. Looks are also necessary.

Read full topic
item.source: Thousands watch Sydney's gay and lesbian Mardi Gras

And yes, I am quite disturbed by drag queens and cross dressers. I don’t think it’s necessary for them to behave like that in public and I’m not the only person disturbed by that.

I’m not trying to debate homosexuality. I just don’t think a massive demonstration of sexuality is appropriate for the streets.

It’s on the streets because It’s an outlandish statement- It’s for recognition- To leave Its footprint.
That’s what everyone’s been saying the whole time.

You think anyone’s going to notice or care If It’s a giant house party?

Why isn’t it necessary for them to behave like that? Because that’s not how you live? Because It’s different? Try being a little more open minded, and less ignorant.

You’re saying the same things over and over again and there is no substance left in your “points”.
It all comes down to that’s not how you like it, It’s not what you want, therefore It shouldn’t exist.

Try reversing the situation. Though It’s hard to feel the impact without actually reversing.

[/quote]
it sounds like u wanna put ur dick in my ass gay fag[/quote]
